rsbNotes.title: John 5:17–47
rsbNotes.text: 5:17–47 Jesus debates the Jews regarding His relation to the Sabbath and to God. Jesus does not argue with His opponents about whether they understand the Sabbath legislation correctly. His interest is whether they understand who He is. Jesus claims to be God by indicating some of His divine prerogatives (vv. 17–30) and shows the basis for His claim (vv. 31–47).

rsbNotes.title: John 5:24
rsbNotes.text: 5:24 eternal life. Salvation is not only an object of hope for the future, but a present reality for the believer; such a one “has passed from death to life” (cf. 6:47).

rsbNotes.title: John 5:26
rsbNotes.text: 5:26 life in himself. See “The Self-existence of God” at Ps. 90:2.

rsbNotes.title: John 5:29
rsbNotes.text: 5:29 resurrection. See “Resurrection and Glorification” at 1 Cor. 15:21.

rsbNotes.title: John 5:31–47
rsbNotes.text: 5:31–47 Jesus addresses four types of testimony that establish His claims: the testimony of John the Baptist; of Jesus’ own works; of God the Father; and of Scripture, especially Moses.

rsbNotes.title: John 5:31
rsbNotes.text: 5:31 my testimony is not deemed true. Jesus’ testimony would not be false even if He alone spoke it. By “not true,” He means not permitted in court according to the Mosaic law (Deut. 17:6; 19:15).

rsbNotes.title: John 5:36
rsbNotes.text: 5:36 the very works that I am doing. This is the principle acknowledged by Nicodemus (3:2). The power given by God to work miracles is a sign of His approval (10:25, 38), although not every wonderful work is a miracle in this sense (Ex. 7:11, 12; Matt. 7:22, 23; 24:24; Rev. 13:13).

rsbNotes.title: John 5:37–38
rsbNotes.text: 5:37, 38 His voice . . . his word. These terms probably refer to Scripture, which is God’s “voice” and “word,” but which the unbelievers did not receive.

rsbNotes.title: John 5:39
rsbNotes.text: 5:39 the Scriptures . . . bear witness about me. Jesus agrees that the Old Testament leads to eternal life (cf. 2 Tim. 3:15), while going on to reveal that this life is in Him, the Author of eternal life. The searching of those who refuse to find Christ in the Scriptures is futile, because it lacks the enlightenment of the Spirit (2 Cor. 3:6).

rsbNotes.title: John 5:45
rsbNotes.text: 5:45 one who accuses you. Moses will accuse those who do not believe in Christ, because Moses wrote about Him. Jesus does not refer to any single text in Moses (such as Deut. 18:15), but to what “he wrote” (v. 46) in a general way. This is similar to what Jesus told His disciples after the resurrection on the road to Emmaus (Luke 24:27, 44–46), as well as to the preaching of the apostles (Acts 3:18; 17:2, 3; 18:28; 26:22, 23; 28:23).
